tit.e: Nara Period
Nara Period
Nara Period

sen.j: 奈良時代（ならじだい、710年-794年）は広義には710年（和銅3年）に元明天皇が平城京に都を移してから、794年（延暦13年）に桓武天皇によって平安京に都が移されるまでの84年間を指す日本の歴史の時代区分の一つ。
sen.e: The Nara Period is a historical period in Japan which is, in broad sense, 84 years from 710 in which the Empress Genmei transferred the capital to Heijokyo to 794 in which the Emperor Kanmu transferred the capital to Heiankyo and, in narrow sense, it is 74 years from 710 to 784 in which the Emperor Kanmu transferred the capital to Nagaokakyo.

The Nara Period was a period in Japan's history which, broadly speaking, lasted 84 years from 710 when the Empress Genmei transferred the capital to Heijokyo to 794 when the Emperor Kanmu transferred the capital to Heiankyo. and,

sen.e: The Nara period was a period in Japan's history which, broadly speaking, lasted 84 years from 710 when the Empress Genmei transferred the capital to Heijokyo to 794 when the Emperor Kanmu transferred the capital to Heiankyo.
sen.cmt: 用語統一しました。余分な単語を削除しました。

sen.j: 狭義には710年から784年（延暦3年）に桓武天皇によって長岡京に都が移されるまでの74年間を指す。
sen.e: In the strict sense, it lasted only 74 years from 710 to 784 when the Emperor Kanmu transferred the capital to Nagaokakyo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In the strict sense, it lasted only 74 years from 710 to 784 when the Emperor Kanmu transferred the capital to Nagaokakyo.

sen.j: 奈良の地に都（平城京）が置かれたことから奈良時代という。
sen.e: Because the capital (Heijokyo) was located in Nara, it is called the Nara Period.
Because the capital (Heijokyo) was located in Nara, it is called the Nara Period.
Because the capital (Heijokyo) was located in Nara, it is called the Nara period.

sen.j: ただし、740年から745年にかけて、聖武天皇は恭仁京（京都府木津川市）、難波京（大阪府大阪市）、紫香楽宮（滋賀県甲賀市）に、それぞれ短期間であるが宮都を遷したことがある。
sen.e: From 740 to 745, however, the Emperor Shomu transferred the capital to Kunikyo (Kizugawa City, Kyoto Prefecture), Nanbakyo (Osaka City, Osaka Prefecture) and Shigaraki no Miya (Koga City, Shiga Prefecture) although it was for a short time period for each capital.

From 740 to 745, however, the Emperor Shomu transferred the capital to Kunikyo (Kizugawa City, Kyoto Prefecture), Nanbakyo (Osaka City, Osaka Prefecture) and Shigaraki no Miya (Koga City, Shiga Prefecture) although each one was only capital for a short time.
sen.cmt: it was for a short time period > each one was only capital for a short time.
sen.e: From 740 to 745, however, the Emperor Shomu transferred the capital to Kunikyo (Kizugawa City, Kyoto Prefecture), Nanbakyo (Osaka City, Osaka Prefecture) and Shigaraki no Miya (Koga City, Shiga Prefecture) although each one was only capital for a short time.

sen.j: 平城京遷都には藤原不比等が重要な役割を果たした。
sen.e: For transfer of the capital to Heijokyo, FUJIWARA no Fuhito played an important role.
FUJIWARA no Fuhito played an important role in the transfer of the capital to Heijokyo
FUJIWARA no Fuhito played an important role in the transfer of the capital to Heijokyo

sen.j: 平城京は、中国の都長安を模した都を造営し、役人が住民の大半を占める政治都市であった。
sen.e: Heijokyo was a political city which was built as the national capital by copying the capital of China, Changan and most of its inhabitants were officials..
Heijokyo was built as a national centre of politics, mainly inhabited by officials, on the model of the capital of China, Changan.
Heijokyo was built as a national centre of politics, mainly inhabited by officials, on the model of the capital of China, Changan.

sen.j: 試行錯誤しながら、律令国家・天皇中心の専制国家・中央集権国家を目指した時代であった。
sen.e: It was an age in which ritsuryo kokka (a nation governed in accordance with ritsuryo codes), despotic nation having the emperor in its center and nation with a centralized government were aimed at by try and error approach, as seen in the fact that Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code) which had been selected and enforced before transfer of the capital to Heijokyo was reviewed from various viewpoints and on various aspects so that it could fit to the actual situations inside Japan.

It was an age which aimed, through trial and error, to create ritsuryo kokka (a nation centrally governed in accordance with Chinese-based legal codes), an autocratic nation centered around the emperor and centralised authority. as seen in the fact that Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code) which had been selected and enforced before transfer of the capital to Heijokyo was reviewed from various viewpoints and on various aspects so that it could fit to the actual situations inside Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It was an age which aimed, through trial and error, to create ritsuryo kokka (a nation centrally governed in accordance with Chinese-based legal codes), an autocratic nation centered around the emperor and centralized authority.
sen.cmt: 後半削除しました。スペル修正しました。

sen.j: 平城京への遷都に先立って撰定・施行された大宝律令が、日本国内の実情に合うように多方面から検討し変更されるなどから上記が分かる。
sen.e: This can be seen in the fact that Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code) - which had been chosen and implemented before the transfer of the capital to Heijokyo - was reviewed and adapted in various ways so that it would be more suitable for real Japanese society.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: This can be seen in the fact that Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code) - which had been chosen and implemented before the transfer of the capital to Heijokyo - was reviewed and adapted in various ways so that it would be more suitable for real Japanese society.

sen.j: また、天平文化が華開いた時代でもあった。
sen.e: Also, it was a period in which Tenpyo culture flourished.
Also, it was a period in which Tenpyo culture (centered around the capital at Heijokyo and the nobles) flourished.
sen.cmt: 天平の説明文を入れました。
sen.e: Also, it was a period in which Tenpyo culture (centered around the capital at Heijokyo and the nobles) flourished.

tit.e: Summary
Summary
Summary

sen.j: 710年に都は奈良の平城京に遷った。
sen.e: In 710, the national capital was transferred to Heijokyo in Nara.
In 710, the national capital was transferred to Heijokyo in Nara.
In 710, the national capital was transferred to Heijokyo in Nara.

sen.j: この時期の律令国家は、戸籍と計帳で人民を把握し、租・庸・調と軍役を課した。
sen.e: The ritsuryo kokka in this period grasped people by koseki (the household registers) and keicho (the yearly tax registers) and imposed soyocho (taxes) and military services.
The ritsuryo kokka in this period maintained control of the people through koseki (the household registers) and keicho (the yearly tax registers) and imposed soyocho (taxes) and military service.
The ritsuryo kokka in this period maintained control of the people through koseki (the household registers) and keicho (the yearly tax registers) and imposed soyocho (taxes) and military service.

sen.j: 遣唐使を度々送り、唐をはじめとする大陸の文物を導入した。
sen.e: Kentoshi (Japanese envoys to Tang Dynasty China) were dispatched rather often and products of culture of the continent, such as Tang were introduced.
Kentoshi (Japanese envoys to Tang Dynasty China) were frequently dispatched and introduced from the culture from the mainland (such as Tang China) to Japan.
Kentoshi (Japanese envoys to Tang Dynasty China) were frequently dispatched and introduced the culture from the mainland (such as Tang China) to Japan.

sen.j: 全国に国分寺を建て、仏教的な天平文化が栄えた。
sen.e: Kokubunji (provincial monasteries) were built all over the country and Tenpyo culture, which was Buddhism culture, flourished.
Kokubunji (provincial monasteries) were built all over the country and the Buddhist Tenpyo culture, flourished.
Kokubunji (provincial monasteries) were built all over the country and the Buddhist Tenpyo culture, flourished.

sen.j: 古事記、日本書紀、万葉集など現存最古の史書・文学が登場した。
sen.e: History books and literatures which are oldest as existing ones such as Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters), Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) and Manyoshu (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves) appeared.

History books and works of literature, which are currently the oldest in existence, such as Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters), Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) and Manyoshu (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves) appeared.

sen.e: History books and works of literature, which are currently the oldest in existence, such as "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters), "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) and "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves) appeared.

sen.j: この時代、中央では政争が多く起こり、東北では蝦夷との戦争が絶えなかった。
sen.e: In this period, many political strifes occurred in the central government and wars with Ezo were repeated in Tokoku and never ceased.
In this period, many political strifes occurred in the central government and in Tohoku there were never-ending wars with Ezo.
In this period, many political strifes occurred in the central government and in Tohoku there were never-ending wars with Ezo.

sen.j: 政治史的には、710年の平城京遷都から729年の長屋王の変までを前期、藤原四兄弟の専権から764年の藤原仲麻呂の乱までを中期、孝謙天皇称徳天皇および道鏡の執政以降を後期に細分できる。
sen.e: From view point of political history view, it can be divided into the early stage from the transfer of the national capital to Heijokyo in 710 to Nagayao (Prince Nagaya) no hen (conspiracy of Nagayao) in 729, the middle stage from the exclusive prerogative by four brothers of the Fujiwara family to the disturbance by FUJIWARA no Nakamaro in 764, and the later stage from administration by the Empress Koken/Shotoku and Dokyo and after that..

From a of political history viewpoint, the period can be divided into three: the Early Stage from the transfer of the capital to Heijokyo in 710 to Nagayao no hen (conspiracy of Prince Nagaya) in 729, the Middle Stage from the arbitary exertion of power by four brothers of the Fujiwara family to the rebellion by FUJIWARA no Nakamaro in 764, and the Later Stage from administration by Dokyo and the Empress Koken (a.k.a. Shotoku) onwards.

From a political history viewpoint, the period can be divided into three: the Early Stage from the transfer of the capital to Heijokyo in 710 to Nagayao no hen (conspiracy of Prince Nagaya) in 729, the Middle Stage from the arbitrary exertion of power by four brothers of the Fujiwara family to the rebellion by FUJIWARA no Nakamaro in 764, and the Later Stage from administration by Dokyo and the Empress Koken (also known as Shotoku) onwards.

tit.j: 東アジア文化圏と奈良時代の対外関係
tit.e: East Asian cultural area and international relations in the Nara Period
East Asian Cultural Sphere and International Relations in the Nara Period

tit.cmt: 文頭のみ大文字にしました。

sen.j: 618年、隋に変わって中国を統一した唐は、大帝国をきずき、東アジアに広大な領域を支配して周辺諸地域に大きな影響をあたえた。
sen.e: Tang which unified China in place Sui Dynasty in 618 built a large empire and controlled a vast territory in East Asia and gave strong influences to neighboring areas.

The Tang Dynasty, who took over from the Sui Dynasty and unified China in 618, built a large empire and controlled a vast territory in East Asia, exerting a strong influence on the neighbouring areas.
sen.cmt: Tang > The tang dynasty. which > who. gave > exerting.
sen.e: The Tang Dynasty, who took over from the Sui Dynasty and unified China in 618, built a large empire and controlled a vast territory in East Asia, exerting a strong influence on the neighboring areas.

sen.j: 西アジアや中央アジアなどとの交流も活発であり、首都長安は国際都市として繁栄した。
sen.e: Interchange with West Asia and Central Asia was also carried out very actively and its national capital, Changan, flourished as an international city and the first half of the era of Emperor Xuan Zong (Tang) was called "Kaigen no chi (this term refers to the political stability of Tang Dynasty when the Emperor Xuan Zong was in power)."
There was also active exchange with West and Central Asia and the capital Changan flourished as an international city.

sen.e: There was also active exchange with West and Central Asia and the capital Changan flourished as an international city.

sen.j: 玄宗 (唐)の治世前半は「開元の治」と称された。
sen.e: The first half of the era of Emperor Xuan Zong (Tang) was called "Kaigen no chi (this term refers to the political stability of the Tang Dynasty during his reign)."

sen.e: The first half of the era of Emperor Xuan Zong (Tang) was called 'Kaigen no chi' (this term refers to the political stability of the Tang Dynasty during his reign).

sen.j: 周辺諸国も唐と通交し、漢字・儒教・漢訳仏教などの諸文化を共有して東アジア文化圏が形成された。
sen.e: Various countries around China had friendly relations with Tang and East Asian cultural area was formed sharing various cultures such as Chinese characters, Confucianism and Buddhism translated into Chinese.

Various countries around China had friendly relations with Tang and the East Asian cultural sphere was formed with shared cultural features such as Chinese characters, Confucianism and Buddhism translated into Chinese.

sen.j: その中にあって日本の律令国家体制では、天皇は中国の皇帝と並ぶものであり、唐と同様、日本を中華とする帝国構造を有していた。
sen.e: Under such situations, in the system of ritsuryo kokka in Japan, the emperor was in a position comparable to the emperor of China and Japan had an imperial structure in which Japan was regarded as the center of the world same as in Tang.

Japan, included in this group of small empires, had a system of ritsuryo kokka, where the emperor was in a position comparable to the emperor of China and Japan had an imperial structure in which Japan was regarded as the center of the world, similarly to Tang.

sen.j: それは国家の統治権が及ぶ範囲を「化内」、それが及ばない外部を「化外」と区別し、さらに化外を区分して唐を「隣国」、朝鮮諸国（この時代には新羅と渤海）を「諸蕃」、蝦夷・隼人・南島人を「夷狄」と規定する「東夷の小帝国」と呼ぶべきものであった。
sen.e: It was a country which should be called "small empire of eastern barbarians" and which classified the area to which its sovereignty reached as "kenai," and the outside of kenai to which its sovereignty did not reach as "kegai.," and, then, classified kegai further into Tang defined as "neighboring country," countries in Korea (Silla and Bokkai (Bohai, kingdom in Manchura and North Korea, established after the fall of Goguryeo, Pohai, Balhae) in this period) as "shoban (literally, miscellaneous barbarians)" and Ezo (northerners), Hayato (an ancient tribe in Kyushu) and inhabitants in southern islands as "iteki."

It was a country worthy of the name "small empire of eastern barbarians" and classified its sphere of sovereignty as "kenai," everywhere outside of this as "kegai" and further classified kegai into Tang (defined as a "neighbouring country") "shoban" (literally, miscellaneous barbarians, consisting of kingdoms in Korea: Silla and Balhae in this period) and "Iteki", including Ezo (northerners), Hayato (an ancient tribe in Kyushu) and inhabitants in southern islands.
sen.cmt: which should be called > worthy of the name. Balhaeが渤海の定訳です。
sen.e: It was a country worthy of the name 'small empire of eastern barbarians' and classified its sphere of sovereignty as 'kenai,' everywhere outside of this as 'kegai' and further classified kegai into Tang (defined as a 'neighboring country') 'shoban' (literally, miscellaneous barbarians, consisting of kingdoms in Korea: Silla and Balhae in this period) and 'Iteki,' including Ezo (northerners), Hayato (an ancient tribe in Kyushu) and inhabitants in southern islands.

sen.j: もちろん律令にそう規定し、それを自負したり目指したことと、とりわけ唐や朝鮮諸国との関係に実態がともなったかどうかは別の問題である。
sen.e: To set forth so in ritsuryo codes and to believe and to aim at it is one thing and whether or not it was realized in the relationship with Tang and countries in Korea, in particular, is another.

Whilst these classifications were set forth in ritsuryo codes, boasted about and strived for, it's another question althogether whether they were actually realized in the relationship with Tang and the Korean kingdoms.

sen.j: 630年の犬上御田鍬にはじまる日本からの遣唐使は、奈良時代にはほぼ20年に1度の頻度で派遣された。
sen.e: Kentoshi (Japanese envoy to Tang Dynasty China) which started from INUGAMI no Mitasuki in 630 were dispatched with the frequency of once in around twenty years in the Nara Period.
Kentoshi (Japanese envoys to Tang Dynasty China,) starting with INUGAMI no Mitasuki in 630, were dispatched roughly once every twenty years in the Nara Period.

sen.j: 大使をはじめとする遣唐使には、留学生や学問僧なども加わり、多いときには約500人におよぶ人びとが4隻の船に乗って渡海した。
sen.e: Kentoshi consisted of approximately 500 persons including the chief of kentoshi and scholars and monks sent to Tang to study and they made voyage to Tang with four vessels.
The envoys consisted of approximately 500 people (including the chief, scholars and monks sent to Tang to study) and they made the voyage to Tang with four vessels.

sen.j: 日本は唐の冊封はうけなかったものの、実質的には唐に臣従する朝貢国の扱いであった。
sen.e: Although Japan did not receive sakuho (homage by Chinese emperor) from Tang, but it was treated substantially as a tributary state which served Tang as a subject.
Although Japan did not receive sakuho (homage by the Chinese emperor) from Tang, it was essentially treated as a tributary state which served Tang as a subject.
Although Japan did not receive sakuho (homage by the Chinese emperor) from Tang, it was essentially treated as a tributary state which served Tang as a subject.

sen.j: 使者は正月の朝賀に参列し、皇帝を祝賀した。
sen.e: Envoys attended choga (retainers' New Year's greeting to the emperor) on the New Year's day and celebrated for the emperor.
Envoys attended Choga (a New Year's greeting to the emperor by retainers) and celebrated the emperor.

sen.e: Envoys attended Choga (a New Year's greeting to the emperor by retainers) and celebrated the emperor.

sen.j: ただし、当時の造船術や航海術はなお未熟な点も多く、海上での遭難も少なくなかった。
sen.e: However, ship building technology and art of navigation at that time had many immature points, and not a few distresses occurred on the sea.
However, ship building technology and the art of navigation at the time were still fairly amateur, and shipwrecks were not uncommon.

sen.j: そのような危険を冒してまで遣唐使たちは、多くの書籍やあるいはすぐれた織物や銀器・陶器・楽器などを数多く持ち帰り、また、唐の先進的な政治制度や国際色豊かな文化をもたらし、当時の日本に多大な影響をあたえた。
sen.e: Although such risks were involved, various kentoshi gave enormous influences to Japan at that time by bringing back a large number of books and excellent textiles, silverware, porcelain and musical instruments and also introducing advanced political system and international cultures of Tang.

Although such risks were involved, these envoys were incredibly influential to Japan at the time, by bringing back large numbers of books and high quality textiles, silverware, porcelain and musical instruments and also introducing advanced political systems and the international culture of Tang.

sen.j: 中でも知識に対する貪欲さはすさまじく、皇帝から下賜された品々を売り払って、その代価ですべて書籍を購入して積み帰ったと唐の正史に記されるほどであった。
sen.e: In particular, their eagerness for knowledge was enormous so that the official history of Tang recorded that some persons from Japan sold goods bestowed by the emperor and spent all the consideration to buy books and took them to Japan.

It is recorded in the official history of Tang that their thirst for knowledge in particular was so insatiable that some people from Japan sold goods bestowed by the emperor and spent all the money to buy books to take back to Japan.

sen.j: とくに、帰国した吉備真備や玄ボウは、のちに聖武天皇に重用され、政治の世界でも活躍した。
sen.e: In particular, KIBI no Makibi and Genbo returned from Tang were given important posts by the Emperor Shomu and played leading roles in the political world in Japan.

sen.cmt: warn against > keep in check. which wasを省略しました。
sen.e: In order to keep Tang, a factor hindering unification of the peninsula, in check, Silla pretended to obey to Japan until the beginning of the eighth century.

sen.j: 渤海の成立後に唐との関係が好転した新羅は、やがて対等外交を主張するようになったが、日本はこれを認めなかった。
sen.e: Silla of which relation with Tang had been developed favorably after the formation of Bokkai, began insisting on equal diplomatic relation but Japan did not agree to it.
After the formation of Balhae, relations between Silla and Tang developed favourably and Silla began insisting on equal diplomatic relations, but Japan did not consent.
sen.cmt: 順番を変え、agree to it > consent.
sen.e: After the formation of Balhae, relations between Silla and Tang developed favorably and Silla began insisting on equal diplomatic relations, but Japan did not consent.

sen.j: 両国の関係悪化は具体化した。
sen.e: Worsening of the relationship between two countries developed into reality.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: The two countries' worsening relationship started to manifest itself in reality.
sen.cmt: developed into > started to manifest itself in
sen.e: The two countries' worsening relationship started to manifest itself in reality.

sen.j: 新羅は日本の侵攻に備えて築城（723年、毛伐郡城）し、日本でも一時軍備強化のため節度使が置かれた。
sen.e: Silla built a castle (毛伐郡城 in 723) to prepare for invasion by Japan and, in Japan also, setsudoshi (military governor) was posted temporarily for the purpose of strengthening armament.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置:「毛伐郡城」読み、定訳不明
sen.e: Silla built a castle (毛伐郡城) in 723 to prepare for a Japanese invasion and, Japan temporarily installed a setsudoshi (military governor) to strengthen armaments.
Silla built a castle (毛伐郡城) in 723 to prepare for a Japanese invasion and, Japan temporarily installed a setsudoshi (military governor) to strengthen armaments.

sen.j: 737年には新羅征討が議論に上ったが、藤原武智麻呂ら4兄弟が相次いで没したため、この時には現実のものとはならなかった。
sen.e: In 737, punitive expedition to Silla was discussed, but, as four brothers including FUJIWARA no Muchimaro died one after another, it was not materialized.
In 737, a punitive expedition to Silla was discussed, but due the the successive deaths of FUJIWARA no Muchimaro and his three brothers it was not materialized.
sen.cmt: aを挿入し、died on e after another>successive deaths.
sen.e: In 737, a punitive expedition to Silla was discussed, but due the successive deaths of FUJIWARA no Muchimaro and his three brothers it was not materialized.

sen.j: 755年、安史の乱が起こり唐で混乱が生じると、新羅に脅威を抱く渤海との関係強化を背景に藤原仲麻呂は新羅への征討戦争を準備している。
sen.e: In 755, when Anshi Rebellion occurred and Tang was put into confusion, FUJIWARA no Nakamaro prepared for war for punitive expedition against Silla based on enhanced relationship with Bokkai which was afraid of Silla.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: In 755, when the Anshi Rebellion occurred and Tang was thrown into disorder, FUJIWARA no Nakamaro made preparations for a punitive war against Silla, based on Japan's stengthening relationship with Balhae (who posed a serious threat to Silla.)
sen.cmt: put into confusion>thrown into disorver. prepared > made preparations enhanced > strengthening. was was afraid of Silla >who pose d aserious threat to.
sen.e: In 755, when the Anshi Rebellion occurred and Tang was thrown into disorder, FUJIWARA no Nakamaro made preparations for a punitive war against Silla, based on Japan's strengthening relationship with Balhae (who posed a serious threat to Silla).
sen.cmt: ピリオド位置移動しました。スペル修正しました。

sen.j: （仲麻呂の没落によりやはり実現しなかった。）
sen.e: (This time also, it was not realized because of fall of Nakamaro.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: (This time also, it was not realized because of fall of Nakamaro.)
(This time also, it was not realized because of fall of Nakamaro.)

sen.j: このように衝突には至らなかったが、新羅の大国意識の高揚により、新羅使も779年を最後に途絶えることとなった。
sen.e: Although no collision occurred as described above, shiragishi (envoy from Silla) was discontinued after the last one in 779 due to increased sense of national greatness of in Silla.
In this way, although no conflict occurred, envoys from Silla were discontinued after the final embassy in 779, due to Silla's rising sense of national greatness and prestige.
sen.cmt: as described above>in this way. siragishi を省略し、increased>rising.
sen.e: In this way, although no conflict occurred, envoys from Silla were discontinued after the final embassy in 779, due to Silla's rising sense of national greatness and prestige.

sen.j: こうした一方で、新羅は民間交易に力を入れた。
sen.e: On the other hand, Silla put its efforts into trade by private sector.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: Meanwhile, Silla concentrated on private sector trade.
sen.cmt: on the other hand>meanwhile. put its efforts into >concentrated on.
sen.e: Meanwhile, Silla concentrated on private sector trade.

sen.j: 唐よりも日本との交流が質量ともに大きかった。
sen.e: Interaction with Japan was bigger than that with Tang both quality- and quantity-wise.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: Interaction with Japan was greater than with Tang in terms of both quality and quantity.
Interaction with Japan was greater than with Tang in terms of both quality and quantity.

sen.j: 現在の正倉院に所蔵されている唐や南方の宝物には新羅商人が仲介したものが少なくないとされている。
sen.e: It is believed that many of treasures from Tang and southern countries kept in the present Shosoin (treasure repository) were mediated by merchants of Silla.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: It is believed that many of treasures from Tang and southern countries currently kept in the Shosoin (treasure repository) were mediated by merchants of Silla.
It is believed that many of treasures from Tang and southern countries currently kept in the Shosoin (treasure repository) were mediated by merchants of Silla.

sen.j: 8世紀末になると遣新羅使の正式派遣は途絶えたが、新羅商人の活動はむしろ活発化している。
sen.e: Around the end of eighth century, official dispatch of kenshiragishi (Japanese envoy to Silla) was discontinued, but merchants of Silla intensified their activities.
Around the end of eighth century, Japanese envoys to Silla were discontinued, but merchants of Silla intensified their activities.
Around the end of eighth century, Japanese envoys to Silla were discontinued, but merchants of Silla intensified their activities.

tit.e: Balhae
Balhae
Balhae

sen.j: 713年、靺鞨族や旧高句麗人（狛族）を中心に中国東北部に建国された渤海 (国)とは緊密な使節の往来がおこなわれた。
sen.e: With Bokkai, which was established in 713 mainly by Makkatsu tribe and people from former Goguryeo(狛族) in the north-eastern area of China, close intercommunication by envoys were conducted.
sen.cmt: 「狛族」 読み、定訳とも不明
sen.e: Japan carried out rigorous diplomatic missions to Balhae, which had been established in 713 mainly by the Makkatsu tribe and people from former Goguryeo(狛族) in the north-eastern area of China.
sen.cmt: Japanを挿入し、順番を変えました。
sen.e: Japan carried out rigorous diplomatic missions to Balhae, which had been established in 713 mainly by the Makkatsu tribe and people from former Goguryeo(狛族) in the north-eastern area of China.
sen.cmt: スペース削除しました。

sen.j: 渤海は、唐・新羅の対抗上727年（神亀4年）に日本に渤海使を派遣して国交を求め、日本に対し臣従するかたちをとった。
sen.e: In 727, Bokkai sent a bokkaisi to Japan asking for diplomatic relations in order to cope with Tang and Silla and assumed to follow Japan.
In 727, Balhae sent an envoy to Japan asking for diplomatic relations in order to cope with Tang and Silla, and became a vassal to Japan.
In 727, Balhae sent an envoy to Japan asking for diplomatic relations in order to cope with Tang and Silla, and became a vassal to Japan.

sen.j: 日本もこれを「蕃国」高句麗の再来としてその朝貢を歓迎し、また新羅との対抗関係から、渤海との通交をきわめて重視し、遣渤海使を派遣した。
sen.e: Japan welcomed this tribute as the recurrence of "barbarian country" Goguryeo and attached a high value to friendly relations with Bokkai to cope with Silla and dispatched kenbokkaishi (Japanese envoy to Bokkai).

Japan welcomed this tribute as the second coming of the "barbarian country" Goguryeo and, highly valuing friendly relations with Balhae in relation to their struggle with Silla, they dispatched envoys.
sen.cmt: recurrence>second coming. attached a high value >highly valuing. to cope with >in relation to their struggle. kenbokkaishi>envoys.
sen.e: Japan welcomed this tribute as the second coming of the 'barbarian country' Goguryeo and, highly valuing friendly relations with Balhae in relation to their struggle with Silla, they dispatched envoys.

sen.j: その渤海も、国力の充実とともに日本に対する「臣従」を必要としなくなった。
sen.e: However, as its national strength got enhances, it became not necessary for Bokkai to follow Japan, and the bokkaishi in 771 was blamed by Japan that johyobun (memorial to the emperor) was impolite.
However, as Balhae consolidated its national strength, it became unnecessary to follow Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: However, as Balhae consolidated its national strength, it became unnecessary to follow Japan.

sen.j: それに対し、771年の渤海使は上表文が無礼であることを日本に非難された。
sen.e: In reaction to this, Japan criticised the envoy sent in 771 for giving an impolite johyobun (memorial to the emperor).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In reaction to this, Japan criticized the envoy sent in 771 for giving an impolite johyobun (memorial to the emperor).

sen.j: その一方で渤海使も交易に比重を置くようになり、来日の頻度も増えていった。
sen.e: On the other hand, bokkaishi began to put stress on trade and frequency of their visits to Japan increased.
On the other hand, envoys from Balhae began to put stress on trade and the frequency of their visits to Japan increased.
On the other hand, envoys from Balhae began to put stress on trade and the frequency of their visits to Japan increased.

sen.j: 平安時代初期には完全に変質したものとなり、824年には右大臣藤原緒嗣が「渤海使は商人であるので、今後は外交使節として扱わないように」と言うほどのものとなった。
sen.e: In the beginning of the Heian Period, bokkaishi had been altered completely and in 824, FUJIWARA no Otsugu, who was udaijin (minister of the right) mentioned "Because bokkaishi are merchants, do not treat them as diplomatic envoys."

In the beginning of the Heian Period, the Balhae envoys had completely transformed to the extent in 824, FUJIWARA no Otsugu, who was udaijin (minister of the right) commented "These men are merchants, so do not treat them as diplomatic envoys."
sen.cmt: bokkaishi>Balhae envoys. altered>transformed. to the extentを入れました。
sen.e: In the beginning of the Heian period, the Balhae envoys had completely transformed to the extent in 824, FUJIWARA no Otsugu, who was udaijin (minister of the right) commented 'These men are merchants, so do not treat them as diplomatic envoys.'
sen.cmt: 用語統一しました。記号を修正しました。

tit.e: Hayato (an ancient tribe in Kyushu) and southern islands
Hayato (an ancient tribe in Kyushu) and the southern islands
Hayato (an ancient tribe in Kyushu) and the southern islands

sen.j: 九州南部には、地下式横穴墓・地下式板石積石室墓・土坑墓などの独特な墓制が維持された地域である。
sen.e: Southern part of Kyushu is an area in which unique institution of tombing such as underground cave tomb, underground plate stone chamber tomb and burial pit was maintained and people in these area were called Kumaso in ancient time and, since the middle of the seventh century, Hayato.
The Southern part of Kyushu is an area which maintains unique methods of burial such as underground cave tombs, underground stone slab tombs and burial pits.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処 was maintained>maintains. institution of tombing>methods of burial. tomb>tombs.
sen.e: The Southern part of Kyushu is an area which maintains unique methods of burial such as underground cave tombs, underground stone slab tombs and burial pits.

sen.j: この地域の人々は古くは熊襲、7世紀後半ごろからは隼人と呼ばれるようになる。
sen.e: People in these areas were known as Kumaso in ancient times and, since the middle of the seventh century, Hayato.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: People in these areas were known as Kumaso in ancient times and, since the middle of the seventh century, Hayato.

sen.j: 5世紀末ごろから徐々に大和王権の影響が浸透していたが、大宝律令が施行された時点でも依然として律令制的支配の及ばない地域だった。
sen.e: Since around the end of the fifth century, influence of the Yamato sovereignty (the ancient Japan sovereignty) gradually penetrated, but it was an area to which control by the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) could not cover even when Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code) was enforced.

Since around the end of the fifth century, influence of the Yamato (ancient Japanese) sovereignty gradually penetrated, but it was an area which the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) could not cover even after the enforcement of the Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code).

Since around the end of the fifth century, influence of the Yamato (ancient Japanese) sovereignty gradually penetrated, but it was an area which the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) could not cover even after the enforcement of the Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code).

sen.j: 699年に三野城・稲積城が築かれ、律令国家は軍事力を背景とした支配を進めはじめる。
sen.e: In 699, Mino-jo Castle and Inazumi-jo Castle were constructed and ritsuryo kokka began to apply control backed with military force.
In 699, Mino-jo Castle and Inazumi-jo Castle were constructed and ritsuryo kokka began to apply control backed by military force.
In 699, Mino-jo Castle and Inazumi-jo Castle were constructed and ritsuryo kokka began to apply control backed by military force.

sen.j: 709年には隼人の朝貢制度が始まり、朝廷において蝦夷とともに異民族たる「夷狄」が服属していることを示し、国家の儀礼において重要な役割を与えられた。
sen.e: In 709, Hayato began to bring tribute to the imperial court that, together with Ezo, "iteki (barbarians)" which were different ethnic groups were subjugated and Hayato was given important role in ceremonies of the nation.

In 709, the Hayato people began to pay tribute to the imperial court, asserting that Ezo and "iteki (barbarians)" - who were considered different race - were to be subjugated, and thus given important role in National ceremonies.
sen.cmt: Hayato>the Hayato people. bring>pay. ceremonies of the nation>national ceremonies.
sen.e: In 709, the Hayato people began to pay tribute to the imperial court, asserting that Ezo and "iteki "(barbarians) - who were considered different race - were to be subjugated, and thus given important role in National ceremonies.

sen.j: しかし支配への抵抗も強く、特に720年には7年前に新設された大隅国の国守陽侯麻呂が殺害される事件が起こった。
sen.e: However, resistance against such control was also strong and, in particular in 720, YAKO no Maro, who was the Governor of Osumi Province, which was established seven years ago, was killed.
However, resistance against such control was also strong and in 720, YAKO no Maro, the Governor of Osumi Province established seven years previously, was killed.
However, resistance against such control was also strong and in 720, YAKO no Maro, the Governor of Osumi Province established seven years previously, was killed.

sen.j: これに対して律令政府は大伴旅人を大将軍として大規模な軍を派遣し、翌年までかかって鎮圧した。
sen.e: As a countermeasure, the ritsuryo government (ancient Japanese government of centralized governance) dispatched a large-scale corps headed by OTOMO no Tabito, as daishogun (commander in chief), and Hayato was suppressed by the next year.
As a countermeasure, the ritsuryo government dispatched a large-scale corps headed by OTOMO no Tabito as daishogun (commander in chief), and the Hayato people were suppressed by the next year.
sen.cmt: 律令の説明文を省略し、Hayato>the Hayato people.
sen.e: As a countermeasure, the ritsuryo government dispatched a large-scale corps headed by OTOMO no Tabito as daishogun (commander in chief), and the Hayato people were suppressed by the next year.

sen.j: その結果722年にははじめて古代の戸籍制度が行われ、以後隼人の組織的な抵抗はなくなった。
sen.e: As a result, the ancient family registration system was applied in 722 for the first time and, since then, there was no organized resistance by Hayato.
As a result, the ancient family registration system was introduced in 722 for the first time and, since then, there was no organized resistance from the Hayato people.
As a result, the ancient family registration system was introduced in 722 for the first time and, since then, there was no organized resistance from the Hayato people.

sen.j: ただ奈良時代における隼人はあくまで朝貢の対象であり、大隅・薩摩国の両国に班田が行われるのは、平安時代に入った800年（延暦19年）のことである。
sen.e: However, Hayato in the Nara Period was merely object of bringing tribute and handensei (state controlled land allotment) was applied to Osumi and Satsuma Provinces only in 800 after the Heian Period commenced.

However, in the Nara Period the Hayato people were merely subject to paying tribute and it was not until, 800 after the start of the Heian Period, that Handensei (state controlled land allotment) was applied to Osumi and Satsuma Provinces
sen.cmt: object>subject. bringing>paying. only in>it was not until.
sen.e: However, in the Nara period the Hayato people were merely subject to paying tribute and it was not until 800, after the start of the Heian period, that Handensei (state controlled land allotment) was applied to Osumi and Satsuma Provinces
sen.cmt: カンマ位置移動しました。用語統一しました。

sen.j: 一方今の南西諸島からは、すでに7世紀の前半から使者が大和王権に「朝貢」するようになっていた。
sen.e: On the other hand, the present Southwest Islands dispatched an envoy to Yamato sovereignty to bring tribute already since the first half of the seventh century.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: On the other hand, the present Southwest Islands had already been dispatching envoys to the Yamato sovereignty to pay tribute since the first half of the seventh century.
On the other hand, the present Southwest Islands had already been dispatching envoys to the Yamato sovereignty to pay tribute since the first half of the seventh century.

sen.j: 698年には覓国使が南島に派遣され、翌年多褹（種子島）、夜久（屋久島）、菴美（奄美大島）、度感（トカラ列島または徳之島）が朝貢に訪れ、702年には行政組織としての多禰国が設置された。
sen.e: In 698, bekkokushi (a group of researchers sent to Kyushu and Northern islands in Japan during the Nara period) was dispatched to Minami-jima Island and, in next year, to Tane (Tanegashima Island), Yaku (Yakushima Island), Amami (Amami Oshima) and Tokara (the Tokara Islands or Tokunoshima Island) brought tribute and, in 702, Tane Province was established as an administrative organization.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: In 698, Bekkokushi (researchers sent to Kyushu and the Northern islands of Japan during the Nara period) were dispatched to Minami-jima Island and the next year Tane (Tanegashima Island), Yaku (Yakushima Island), Amami (Amami Oshima) and Tokara (the Tokara Islands or Tokunoshima Island) came to pay tribute and, in 702, Tane Province was established as an administrative organization.

In 698, Bekkokushi (researchers sent to Kyushu and the Northern islands of Japan during the Nara period) were dispatched to Minami-jima Island and the next year Tane (Tanegashima Island), Yaku (Yakushima Island), Amami (Amami Oshima) and Tokara (the Tokara Islands or Tokunoshima Island) came to pay tribute and, in 702, Tane Province was established as an administrative organization.

sen.j: 南島からは工芸品の材料となる夜光貝や赤木といった特産物がもたらされ、また南島へは鉄器がもたらされた。
sen.e: Special products such as yakogai (turban shell, lunica marmorata) and bishop wood (Bischofia javanica), which were used as materials for handicrafts, were brought from Minami-jima Island and iron wares were brought to Minami-jima Island.

Special products such as yakogai (turban shell, lunica marmorata) and bishop wood (Bischofia javanica), which were used as materials for handicrafts,were brought from Minami-jima Island in return for iron wares.

Special products such as yakogai (turban shell, lunica marmorata) and bishop wood (Bischofia javanica), which were used as materials for handicrafts, were brought from Minami-jima Island in return for iron wares.
sen.cmt: スペース挿入しました。

sen.j: 大宰府跡からは「掩美嶋」（奄美大島）・「伊藍嶋」（沖永良部島か）と書かれた木簡が出土しており、また奄美大島奄美市の小湊・フワガネク遺跡から夜光貝による貝匙製作跡が見つかっている。
sen.e: From the ruin of Dazaifu, mokkan (a narrow strip of wood on which an official message is written) with characters "Amamishima" (Amami-Oshima Island) and "Irabu-jima" (Oki-no-erabujima Island) was unearthed and vestige of manufacture of spoons with shells of yakogai was found in from Kominato, Fuwaganeku ruins in Amami City of Amami Oshima Island.

From the ruin of Dazaifu, mokkan (a narrow strip of wood on which an official message is written) with characters "Amamishima" (Amami-Oshima Island) and "Irabu-jima" (Oki-no-erabujima Island) was unearthed and vestiges of the manufacture of spoons with shells of yakogai were found in from Kominato, Fuwaganeku ruins in Amami City of Amami Oshima Island.

From the ruin of Dazaifu, mokkan (a narrow strip of wood on which an official message is written) with characters 'Amamishima' (Amami-Oshima Island) and 'Irabu-jima' (Oki-no-erabujima Island) was unearthed and vestiges of the manufacture of spoons with shells of yakogai were found in Kominato, Fuwaganeku ruins in Amami City of Amami Oshima Island.
sen.cmt: 記号を修正しました。余分な単語を削除しました。

sen.j: しかし9世紀になると「国なくして敵なく、損ありて益なし」といわれたように律令国家の関心は薄くなっていった。
sen.e: However, as the ninth century began, interest of ritsuryo kokka was weakened as mentioned like "If there is no nation, there is no enemy and there is only loss but no profit."
However, as the ninth century began, interest in ritsuryo kokka weakened as we can see from sources such as, "If there is no nation, there is no enemy and there is only loss but no profit."
sen.cmt: interest in>interest of. as mentined like>as we can see from sources such as
sen.e: However, as the ninth century began, interest in ritsuryo kokka weakened as we can see from sources such as, 'If there is no nation, there is no enemy and there is only loss but no profit.'
sen.cmt: 記号を修正しました。スペース削除しました。

tit.e: Ezo
Ezo
Ezo

sen.j: 歴史上、蝦夷と呼ばれる人々がどのような人々であったのかはいまだにさまざまな論がある.。
sen.e: Even today there are various views on what was people who were historically called Ezo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: Even today there are various theories as to what kind of people the Ezo were.
sen.cmt: views>theories. what was>what kind of people.
sen.e: Even today there are various theories as to what kind of people the Ezo were.

sen.j: 何であれ中華思想に基づいた律令国家にとっては、「自らの支配下の外側にある人々という概念でしかな」かった。
sen.e: Whatever they may be, for ritsuryo kokka based on "Sinocentrism," Ezo was just a concept of people who were out of their control.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: Whatever they may have been, for the ritsuryo kokka based on "Sinocentrism," Ezo was simply a concept of people who were out of their control.
Whatever they may have been, for the ritsuryo kokka based on Sinocentrism, Ezo was 'simply a concept of people who were out of their control.'

sen.j: 7世紀半ばに阿倍比羅夫らが遠征し、現在の秋田や津軽地方、さらにその北方に至ったとされる。
sen.e: In the middle of the seventh century, ABE no Hirafu and others made expeditions and it is believed that they reached the present Akita and Tsugaru regions or even to their north.

sen.j: 律令制下の天皇には、以下のような権力があった。
sen.e: The emperor had the following power and authority under the ritsuryo system.

sen.j: 貴族や官人の官職及び官位を改廃する権限、令外官（りょうげのかん）の設置権、官人の叙位および任用権限、五衛府（ごえふ）や軍団兵士に対するすべての指揮命令権、罪刑法定主義を原則とする律の刑罰に対して勅断権と大赦権、外国の使者や外国へ派遣する使者に対する詔勅の使用などの外交権、皇位継承の決定権などである。
sen.e: The above mentioned power and authority included power and authority to establish and abolish government posts and official court ranks for nobles and officials, authority to post ryoge no kan (post outside the original ritsuryo code created by imperial edicts), authority of joi (investiture of a court rank) and to appoint officials, right to give command to all soldiers of goefu (five palace guards) and all other corps, right to make imperial judgment and right to grant general amnesty with respect to punishments under ritsu codes for which the principle of "nulla poena sine lege" (principle of legality) is the principle, the diplomatic rights such as right to use shochoku (imperial edict) to the foreign envoys and envoys to foreign countries and right to decide on succession to the Imperial Throne.

The authority to establish and abolish government posts and official court ranks for nobles and officials, the right to appoint Ryoge no kan (a new governmental post), the authority to bestow court rank and to appoint officials, all rights of leadership and command towards army corps, soldiers and goefu (Palace guards), the right to make imperial judgment and right to grant general amnesty with respect to punishments under ritsu codes - these were based on the principle of legality, diplomatic rights such as right to use shochoku (the Imperial edict) on envoys to and from foreign countries and right to decide on succession to the Imperial Throne.

sen.j: この法では、新しく灌漑施設をつくって開墾した者は三代のあいだ、もとからある池溝を利用した者は本人一代にかぎり、墾田の保有を認めた。

sen.e: In January 708 which was the next year of the enthronement of the Empress Genmei, the name of the era was changed to "Wado" after presentation of cupper from Musashi Province and, in February next year, production of coins and construction of the capital were commenced.

sen.e: It is sometimes assumed the reason of avoidance was that the position of Fujiwarakyo was lower than the area in which large number of subjects lived and subjects could look down the capital.

sen.e: Not only because of them, however, but because Fujiwarakyo was constructed in a period in which interaction with Tan was disrupted, it seemed to have been designed in accordance with the old book ("Shurei (Rites of Zhou)") and it has no comparable example among capitals of China in that era.

sen.j: 実際には、30数年ぶりに帰国した遣唐使の粟田真人が朝政にくわわってこれらの問題が明るみになった。
sen.e: In reality, however, it seems that AWATA no Mahito, who was a kentoshi and returned to Japan after over 30 years, joined the government by the Imperial Court and made such problems clear and reported on culture, power of the nation and dignity and prosperity of the capital, Changan, of Tang caused the government become conscious of the large difference between Fujiwarakyo and Changan resulting in the decision of the transfer of the capital

sen.j: また唐の文化や国力、首都長安の偉容や繁栄などを報告したことが、藤原京と長安との差がかけ離れていることを自覚することとなって、遷都を決めた要因となったと考えられる。
sen.e: Also, his reporting on culture, power of the nation and the dignity and prosperity of the capital, Changan, of Tang made the government conscious of the large difference between Fujiwarakyo and Changan, which resulted in the decision to transfer the capital.

sen.j: その根底には、壮麗な都を建設することが、外国使節や蝦夷・隼人などの辺境民、そして地方豪族や民衆に対して天皇の徳を示すことに他ならずとする考えがあった。

sen.j: 国内的には中央集権的な支配を確立するとともに、東夷の小「中華帝国」を目指したものに他ならなかった。
sen.e: Domestically, it was to aim consolidation of centralized control and a "little Sino-centrism country" by eastern barbarians.

sen.j: 9月、元明天皇はみずから平城の地を視察し、造平城京司の長官ら17名を任命した。

sen.e: In November, she provided corn and cloth to private families which were forced to move from the site of Heijo-kyu Palace.

sen.j: この年（和銅元年）、遷都を主導した藤原不比等は正二位、右大臣に進み、不比等の後妻、県犬養三千代は女帝の大嘗祭において杯に浮かぶタチバナとともに「橘宿禰」の姓を賜った。
sen.e: In this year (708), FUJIWARA no Fuhito, who led the transfer of the capital was promoted to Shonii Udaijin (Senior Second Rank, Chief of an Imperial Japanese Council of State) and his second wife, Agata no INUKAI no Michiyo, was given the family name of "Tachibana no Sukune" together with tachibana (mandarin orange) floating in the cup on the occasion of daijosai (first ceremonial offering of rice by newly enthroned emperor/empress) for the Empress.

sen.j: 地名や職掌にかかわる名が一般的ななかで植物の名を氏名とするのは稀有なことであり、彼女の生んだ皇子たちは橘を名のって、橘氏の実質上の祖となった。
sen.e: As names related to place name or official duty were popular, it was seldom to use the name of plant as a family name, and imperial princes born from her used the family name of Tachibana and became virtual founder of the Tachibana clan.

sen.j: なお、これにより橘諸兄と改名した葛城王と、のちに皇后となる光明子（光明皇后）とは、三千代を母とする異父同母の兄妹にあたる。
sen.e: Prince Katsuragi who changed his name to TACHIBNA no Moroe because of this and Komyoshi (Empress Komyo), who became empress later, were brother and sister having Michiyo as mother but from different father.

sen.j: 平城京の特色としては「外京」という左京からの張り出し部分を設けたことで、完全な矩形ではないことである。
sen.e: A unique point of Heijokyo was that a section called "gekyo" protruded from sakyo was provided and, therefore, the outer shape of the capital was not completely square.

sen.e: Buildings existed in Heijokyo were not limited to buildings of Tang style but there were many buildings of traditional Japanese style, which were dug-standing pillar buildings for takayukashiki-soko (warehouse on stilts) with wooden plate floor and hiwadabuki roof (cypress bark roof).

Buildings in Heijokyo were not limited to Tang style; there were many buildings of traditional Japanese style, warehouses on stilts supported by pillars dug into the ground, with wooden plate floors and hiwadabuki (cypress bark) roofs known as takayukashiki-soko.

sen.j: 729年（神亀6年）、左大臣にのぼった長屋王に対し藤原四兄弟は「左道によって国政を傾ける」と讒訴して、自殺に追いこみ（長屋王の変）、政権を手にした。
sen.e: In 729, the four brothers of Fujiwara slandered Nagayao, who had been promoted to sadaijin (minister of the left) as "endangering the nation by 左道" and forced him to commit suicide (Nagayao no Hen) and obtained reins of government.

sen.j: 仲麻呂は独裁的な権力を手中にし、傀儡（かいらい）として淳仁天皇を擁立し、みずからを唐風に恵美押勝と改名し、儒教を基本とする中国風の政治を推進した。

sen.e: After FUJIWARA no Tanetsugu, who was responsible for the construction, was assassinated and Imperial Prince Sawara, who was a younger brother of the Emperor Kanmu was arrested, a new capital was constructed in 794 and Yamashiro Province (山背国) was changed to Yamashiro Province (山城国) and the new capital was named Heiankyo and the capital was transferred.

Rise of Buddhism
Rise of Buddhism

sen.j: 奈良時代の仏教は、鎮護国家の思想とあいまって国家の保護下に置かれていよいよ発展し、国を守るための法会や祈祷がさかんにおこなわれた。
sen.e: In the Nara Period, Buddhism developed thanks to protection by the national government as well as thought of chingo kokka and hoe (Buddhist mass) and prayer to protect the nation were held very often.
In the Nara Period, Buddhism developed thanks to protection by the government as well as the idealogy of Chingo kokka and Hoe (Buddhist mass) and prayers to protect the nation were often held.
In the Nara period, Buddhism developed thanks to protection by the government as well as the ideology of Chingo kokka and Hoe (Buddhist mass) and prayers to protect the nation were often held.
sen.cmt: 用語統一しました。スペル修正しました。

sen.j: 政府は平城京内に大寺院をたて、聖武天皇は、741年（天平13）に全国に詔して、国分寺や国分尼寺を全国に建てさせた。
sen.e: The government built large temples in Heijokyo and, in 741, the Emperor Shomu issued an imperial edict to each Province and made them build kokubunji and kokubunniji.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: The government built large temples in Heijokyo and, in 741, the Emperor Shomu issued an imperial edict to each Province and made them build kokubunji and kokubunniji.
The government built large temples in Heijokyo and, in 741, the Emperor Shomu issued an imperial edict to each Province and made them build kokubunji and kokubunniji.
sen.cmt: スペース削除しました。

sen.j: また良弁を開山の師として東大寺の造営をおこない、743年（天平15）には、東大寺盧舎那仏像（大仏）の造立を発願し、国家の安泰を願った。
sen.e: It also constructed Todai-ji Temple having Roben as the founder and, in 743, wished construction of the statue of Birushana Buddha in Todai-ji Temple (Daibutsu) praying for peaceful nation.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: They also constructed Todai-ji Temple, naming Roben as its founder and, in 743, ordered construction of the statue of Birushana Buddha in Todai-ji Temple (Daibutsu) praying for a peaceful nation.
They also constructed Todai-ji Temple, naming Roben as its founder and, in 743, ordered construction of the statue of Birushana Buddha in Todai-ji Temple (Daibutsu) praying for a peaceful nation.

sen.j: 大仏の造立は、紫香楽宮で始まった。
sen.e: Construction of daibutsu was commenced in Shigaraki no Miya Palace.
Construction of daibutsu commenced in Shigaraki no Miya Palace.
Construction of daibutsu commenced in Shigaraki no Miya Palace.

sen.j: 752年（天平勝宝4）には、出家し、退位した聖武太上天皇・光明皇后・聖武の娘である孝謙天皇らが、東大寺に行幸し、大仏の開眼供養を行った。
sen.e: In 752, retired Shomu Daijo Tenno (retired emperor), the Empress Komyo and the Empress Koken, who was a daughter of Shomu visited Todai-ji Temple and held ceremony to consecrate the daibutsu.
In 752, retired Emperor Shomu Daijo, the Empress Komyo and his daughter Empress Koken visited Todai-ji Temple and held a ceremony to consecrate the daibutsu.
sen.cmt: who was a daughter of Shomu>his daughter
sen.e: In 752, Retired Emperor Shomu Daijo, the Empress Komyo and his daughter Empress Koken visited Todai-ji Temple and held a ceremony to consecrate the daibutsu.

sen.j: さらに孝謙天皇が重祚した称徳天皇は西大寺 (奈良市)を建立した。
sen.e: The Empress Shotoku, who was the Empress Koken enthroned again, constructed Saidai-ji Temple (Nara City).
Empress Koken was enthroned again as Shotoku and constructed Saidai-ji Temple (Nara City).
Empress Koken was enthroned again as Shotoku and constructed Saidai-ji Temple (Nara City).

sen.j: 僧侶は南都七大寺(大安寺、薬師寺、元興寺、興福寺、東大寺、西大寺、法隆寺）などの寺において仏教の教理を研究し、南都六宗（三論宗、成実宗、法相宗、倶舎宗、華厳宗、律宗）という学派が形成された。
sen.e: Monks studied Buddhist theory in nanto shichidaiji (Seven Great Temples of Nara)(Daian-ji Temple, Yakushi-ji Temple, Genko-ji Temple, Kofuku-ji Temple, Todai-ji Temple, Saidai-ji Temple and Horyu-ji Temple) and sects called nanto rokushu (six sects in Nara) (Sanron sect, Jojitsu sect, Hosso sect, Kusha sect, Kegon sect, and Ritsu sect) were formed.

Monks studied Buddhist theory in the Seven Great Temples of Nara (Daian-ji Temple, Yakushi-ji Temple, Genko-ji Temple, Kofuku-ji Temple, Todai-ji Temple, Saidai-ji Temple and Horyu-ji Temple) and sects called Nanto rokushu "six Nara sects" (Sanron sect, Jojitsu sect, Hosso sect, Kusha sect, Kegon sect, and Ritsu sect) were formed.

Monks studied Buddhist theory in the Seven Great Temples of Nara (Daian-ji Temple, Yakushi-ji Temple, Genko-ji Temple, Kofuku-ji Temple, Todai-ji Temple, Saidai-ji Temple and Horyu-ji Temple) and sects called Nanto rokushu "six Nara sects" (Sanron sect, Jojitsu sect, Hosso sect, Kusha sect, Kegon sect, and Ritsu sect) were formed.

sen.j: 大規模な写経もおこなわれており、特に光明皇后発願の一切経の写経事業は、大仏造立や国分寺造営とならぶ大事業であった。
sen.e: A large-scale activities of copying of a sutra were conducted and, in particular, activities of copying complete Buddhist scriptures carried out by wish of the Empress Komyo was a great undertaking comparable to construction of diabutu and kokubunji.
Large-scale copying of sutras was conducted and, Empress Komyo's order for a complete copy of all Buddhist scriptures was a great undertaking comparable to construction of diabutu and kokubunji.
Large-scale copying of sutras was conducted and, Empress Komyo's order for a complete copy of all Buddhist scriptures was a great undertaking comparable to construction of daibutsu and kokubunji.

sen.j: 仏教の発展は、遣唐使にしたがって留学した道慈（三論宗）や玄ボウ（法相宗）ら学問僧たちの努力によるところが大きい。
sen.e: Development of Buddhism owed largely to efforts of gakumonso (literally, studying monks) such as Doji (Sanron sect) and Genbo (Hosso sect) who visited Tang to learn accompanying kentoshi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: Development of Buddhism was owed largely to the efforts of gakumonso (literally, studying monks) such as Doji (of the Sanron sect) and Genbo (of the Hosso sect) who accompanied the envoys to Tang to study.

Development of Buddhism was owed largely to the efforts of gakumonso (literally, studying monks) such as Doji (of the Sanron sect) and Genbo (of the Hosso sect) who accompanied the envoys to Tang to study.

sen.j: 754年（天平勝宝6年）1月に6度目の航海のすえに平城京に到着して、戒律や多数の経典を伝えた唐出身の鑑真和尚、大仏開眼供養の導師となったインド出身の菩提僊那、菩提僊那と同時に来日したチャンパ王国（林邑）出身の僧仏哲、唐僧道セン、また、多くの新羅僧ら外国出身の僧侶の活動に負うところも大きかった。
sen.e: It also owed to activities of foreign monks such as Ganjin (Jianzhen) wajo from Tang who arrived in January 754 in Heijokyo on his sixth try of voyage to Japan and introduced the precepts of Buddhism and brought a large number of Buddhist scriptures, Bodai Senna from India who acted as kaigan doshi (an officiating priest to consecrate a newly made Buddhist statue or image by inserting the eyes) for daibutsu, Buttetsu, a monk from the kingdom of Champa (Lin Yi (Vietnam called in Chinese in the past)) who came to Japan at the same time as Bodai Senna, Dosen who was a monk from Tang and a large number of monks from Silla.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: It also owed to activities of foreign monks such as Ganjin (Jianzhen) wajo from Tang who arrived in January 754 in Heijokyo on his sixth attempted voyage to Japan and introduced the precepts of Buddhism, bringing a large number of Buddhist scriptures, Bodai Senna from India who acted as Kaigan doshi (an officiating priest to consecrate a newly made Buddhist statue or image by inserting the eyes) for the daibutsu, Buttetsu, a monk from the kingdom of Champa (Lin Yi, a former name for Vietnam) who came to Japan at the same time as Tang monk Bodai Senna (Dosen) and a large number of monks from Silla.

It also owed to activities of foreign monks such as Ganjin (Jianzhen) wajo from Tang who arrived in January 754 in Heijokyo on his sixth attempted voyage to Japan and introduced the precepts of Buddhism, bringing a large number of Buddhist scriptures, Bodai Senna from India who acted as Kaigan doshi (an officiating priest to consecrate a newly made Buddhist statue or image by inserting the eyes) for the daibutsu, Buttetsu, a monk from the kingdom of Champa (Lin Yi, a former name for Vietnam) who came to Japan at the same time as Tang monk Bodai Senna (Dosen) and a large number of monks from Silla.

sen.j: 朝廷は国教として仏教を保護するいっぽう、「僧尼令」などの法令によってきびしく統制し、僧侶になる手続きや資格をさだめて仏教の民間布教に制限を加えた。
sen.e: While protecting Buddhism as a state religion, the Imperial Court controlled it strictly with laws and regulations such as Soni ryo (Regulations for Monks and Nuns) and restricted missionary activities on private basis of Buddhism by stipulating procedures to become and qualification of monks and nuns.

While protecting Buddhism as a state religion, the Imperial Court controlled it strictly with laws and regulations such as Soni ryo (Regulations for Monks and Nuns) and restricted private missionary activities by stipulating procedures and qualifications to become a monk or nun.

While protecting Buddhism as a state religion, the Imperial Court controlled it strictly with laws and regulations such as Soni ryo (Regulations for Monks and Nuns) and restricted private missionary activities by stipulating procedures and qualifications to become a monk or nun.

sen.j: しかし、行基のように禁令にそむいて民間への布教をおこない、弾圧されたものの灌漑設備や布施屋の設置、道路建設などの社会事業に尽力し、民衆の支持を集める僧侶もあった。
sen.e: On the other hand, there was a monk like Gyoki who missioned the general public violating ban and, notwithstanding crackdown, was supported by general public for his efforts in social owrks such as provision of irrigation system and fuseya (aid station or rest house) as well as road construction.

On the other hand, there were monks such as Gyoki who violated these restrictions and preached to the general public, and, although he was suppressed, he was also supported by general public for his efforts in social work such as provision of irrigation systems and fuseya (aid station or rest house) as well as road construction.
sen.cmt: was a >were. violating ban>violated these restriction. notwithstanding crackdown>althoguh he was suppressed
sen.e: On the other hand, there were monks such as Gyoki who violated these restrictions and preached to the general public, and, although he was suppressed, he was also supported by general public for his efforts in social work such as provision of irrigation systems and fuseya (aid station or rest house) as well as road construction.

sen.j: 行基は結局、その人気に注目した政府によって登用され、大仏建立に尽力したことで大僧正の僧位を得た。
sen.e: At the end, Gyoki was adopted by the government that noticed his popularity and promoted to daisojo (a Buddhist priest of the highest order) for his efforts and contribution to construction of daibutsu.
In the end, the government noticed Gyoki's popularity and took him on, promoting him daisojo (a Buddhist priest of the highest order) for his efforts and contribution to construction of daibutsu.
In the end, the government noticed Gyoki's popularity and took him on, promoting him daisojo (a Buddhist priest of the highest order) for his efforts and contribution to construction of daibutsu.
sen.cmt: スペース削除しました。

sen.j: 他に社会事業をおこなった人物としては、行基の師で宇治橋をつくったといわれる道昭（法相宗の開祖）、貧窮した民衆を救済するための悲田院・施薬院を設けた光明皇后、多数の孤児を養育した和気広虫などがいる。
sen.e: As persons who carried out social works, there were Dosho (originator of Hosso sect) who was the teacher for Gyoki, the Empress Komyo who established Hidenin and Seyauin to give relief to poor people, and WAKE no Hiromushi who brought up a large number of orphans.

Others who carried out social works include Dosho (founder of the Hosso sect) who was Gyoki's teacher, the Empress Komyo who established Hidenin and Seyauin to give relief to poor people, and WAKE no Hiromushi who brought up a large number of orphans.

Others who carried out social works include Dosho (founder of the Hosso sect) who was Gyoki's teacher and said to have built Uji-bashi Bridge, the Empress Komyo who established Hidenin and Seyauin to give relief to poor people, and WAKE no Hiromushi who brought up a large number of orphans.
